title: How to Add Videos & Movies to an iPod

steps.title: Visit the iTunes Store.
steps.content: Visit the iTunes Store. Any video you buy from the iTunes Store will play in your iPod.

steps.title: Download and pay for the video.
steps.content: Download and pay for the video.

steps.title: Select the video for your iPod.
steps.content: Select the video for your iPod.

steps.title: Know the formats.
steps.content: Know the formats. Your iPod can only play .m4v, .mp4 or .mov files. Your video should be a .mov file. If it doesn't have this extension, you'll need to convert it. Otherwise, simply open it in iTunes and sync to your iPod.

steps.title: Convert with Apple software.
steps.content: Convert with Apple software. If you're using a Mac, you can use QuickTime Pro to convert your file into an iPod-friendly format. Download and install QuickTime Player Pro 7.0.3 Select or import your video file. Select File->Export From the Export drop-down list choose Movie to iPod . A new file will be created on your Desktop. Import this file into iTunes and sync your iPod.

steps.title: Download third-party software.
steps.content: Download third-party software. There are several third-party applications available for download online that will convert your video file to .mov. For Windows, Videora, PQDVD, 3GP Convert, Leawo Free iPod Converter, Any Video Converter (that is the title), and Handbrake are popular choices. For Macintosh, use Handbrake or VideoMonkey. If you're having a hard time figuring out the process, type "[software] help forum" into an online search, with [software] filled in with the name of the application you downloaded.

steps.title: Select File->Import.
steps.content: Select File->Import . The movie imports into iTunes.

steps.title: Select the movie with a single click.
steps.content: Select the movie with a single click.

steps.title: You can also right-click on the movie file icon and select this option.
steps.content: You can also right-click on the movie file icon and select this option.

steps.title: Select the new file created to sync.
steps.content: Select the new file created to sync.

steps.title: Figure out if your file is muxed.
steps.content: Figure out if your file is muxed. If your video plays on the iPod but you have no sound, that means your sound is muted or in an incompatible format. When files are muxed, they contain interleaved audio and video tracks, which are mixed together instead of being stored as separate tracks. Here's how to figure it out. Open the original movie file in QuickTime Player. From the Window menu, chose Show Movie Info . Click the More Info disclosure triangle in the Movie Info window (if it's closed). Note the entry next to "Format." If the format is "MPEG1 Muxed" or "MPEG2 Muxed," the audio portion of your video file is incompatible with your iPod and iTunes applications, and with anything else based on QuickTime. There is not fix for this other than to use a third party application to convert all of the file.
